Package io

Class TextFileFilter

java.lang.Object
javax.swing.filechooser.FileFilter
io.TextFileFilter
public class TextFileFilter
extends javax.swing.filechooser.FileFilter
This class filters files from showing up in the open dialog box. It only allows those of specified extension to be visible.

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors
    Constructor Description
    TextFileFilter()
    Creates a file filter that accepts the given file type.

  • Method Summary

    Returns the human readable description of this filter.
    java.lang.String getExtension​(java.io.File f)
    Return the extension portion of the file's name .
    boolean isExtensionListInDescription()
    Returns whether the extension list (.jpg, .gif, etc) should show up in the human readable description.

    Sets the human readable description of this filter.

    Determines whether the extension list (.jpg, .gif, etc) should show up in the human readable description.

  • Constructor Details

    • TextFileFilter

      public TextFileFilter()
      Creates a file filter that accepts the given file type. Example: new ExampleFileFilter("jpg", "JPEG Image Images"); Note that the "." before the extension is not needed. If provided, it will be ignored.
      See Also:
      addExtension(java.lang.String)

  • Method Details

    • accept

      public boolean accept​(java.io.File f)
      Return true if this file should be shown in the directory pane, false if it shouldn't. Files that begin with "." are ignored.
      Specified by:
      accept in class javax.swing.filechooser.FileFilter
      Parameters:
      f - A File to check.
      Returns:
      whether this filter accepts this File.
      See Also:
      getExtension(java.io.File)

    • getExtension

      public java.lang.String getExtension​(java.io.File f)
      Return the extension portion of the file's name .
      Parameters:
      f - A File object from which to retrieve its extension.
      Returns:
      A String containing the File's extension.
      See Also:
      getExtension(java.io.File), FileFilter.accept(java.io.File)

    • addExtension

      public void addExtension​(java.lang.String extension)
      Adds a file type "dot" extension to filter against. For example: the following code will create a filter that filters out all files except those that end in ".jpg" and ".tif": ExampleFileFilter filter = new ExampleFileFilter(); filter.addExtension("jpg"); filter.addExtension("tif"); Note that the "." before the extension is not needed and will be ignored.
      Parameters:
      extension - A String with an extension to add to the filter.

    • getDescription

      public java.lang.String getDescription()
      Returns the human readable description of this filter. For example: "JPEG and GIF Image Files (*.jpg, *.gif)"
      Specified by:
      getDescription in class javax.swing.filechooser.FileFilter
      See Also:
      setDescription(java.lang.String), setExtensionListInDescription(boolean), isExtensionListInDescription(), FileFilter.getDescription()

    • setDescription

      public void setDescription​(java.lang.String description)
      Sets the human readable description of this filter. For example: filter.setDescription("Gif and JPG Images");
      Parameters:
      description - The description of the extensions this filter looks for.
      See Also:
      setDescription(java.lang.String), setExtensionListInDescription(boolean), isExtensionListInDescription()

    • setExtensionListInDescription

      public void setExtensionListInDescription​(boolean b)
      Determines whether the extension list (.jpg, .gif, etc) should show up in the human readable description. Only relevant if a description was provided in the constructor or using setDescription();
      Parameters:
      b - whether the extension list will show up in the description.
      See Also:
      getDescription(), setDescription(java.lang.String), isExtensionListInDescription()

    • isExtensionListInDescription

      public boolean isExtensionListInDescription()
      Returns whether the extension list (.jpg, .gif, etc) should show up in the human readable description. Only relevant if a description was provided in the constructor or using setDescription();
      Returns:
      whether the extension list will show up in the description.
      See Also:
      getDescription(), setDescription(java.lang.String), setExtensionListInDescription(boolean)
